name: borehole heat exchanger production, 150m | borehole heat exchanger, 150m | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/2368/documentation

This dataset represents the installation of a borehole heat exchanger for an average one family house in the Swiss midland. For this, two U-shaped polyethylene tubes are installed in a borehole in the ground with a diameter of about 12 cm and a depth of 150 meters. Life time is assumed to be 50 years. This dataset is dimensioned for a heat pump system with the following reference values: for the average one family house a heating requirement of 10 kW, a heat distribution system (low-temperature system) of 50/40°C and a heat supply of approximately 20.000 kWh with 2.000 operating hours were assumed. Furthermore, a system with a heating output of 10,25 kW (at a supply temperature of 40°C), a mean cooling capacity of 8,25 kW (to dimension the borehole heat exchanger) and a extraction performance of 55 W/m were chosen. The heat pump system is assumed to be operated without an auxiliary heating system. Switzerland is assumed to represent an average climatological and geological location in Europe.;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

From reception of the various construction and drilling materials (reinforcing steel, cement, activated bentonite, ethylene glycol, polyethylene) at the drilling company. 

This activity ends with a borehole heat exchanger unit with a life time of 50 years.This dataset includes emissions during drilling phase. The dataset doesn´t include the recycling process of bentonite, nor operation of the borehole heat exchanger.
category: C:Manufacturing/28:Manufacture of machinery and equipment n.e.c./281:Manufacture of general-purpose machinery/2819:Manufacture of other general-purpose machinery

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Borehole heat exchangers basically consist of coaxial or U-shaped polyethylene tubes and are installed vertically in the soil, usually at a depth of 50 up to 250 meters.Up to a depth of 75 meters a tube with a diameter of 25 mm (0,172 kg/m) is inserted, for deeper probes a tube with a diameter of 32 mm (0,273 kg/m) is used. If a borehole heat exchanger with a length of 150 meters should be installed, 30 % use two probes with a length of 75 meters and in 70 % of the cases one probe with a length of 150 meters is installed.;;For brine-water heat pumps with a borehole heat exchanger soil serves as heat source. The heat is withdrawn from the soil through a closed-loop system situated in the tube and is fed to the heat pump. As heat-conveying fluid, i.e. brine, in the majority of cases water is used compounded with 25 % to 35% of antifreezing agent. Borehole heat exchangers are backfilled with a bentonite-cement suspension to ensure good thermal contact between the probe and the ground, i.e. to increase heat transfer. ;;Through the operation of borehole heat exchangers heat is extracted constantly from the soil. Due to the fact that the soil is not able to compensate the thermal deficit, a funnel-shaped low-temperature area is formed round the borehole heat exchanger with a temperature difference (located 2,5 meters away from the tube) between soil temperature without operation of a borehole heat exchanger and with operation of below 1 degree C. During heating period heat pumps are in operation most of the time so the soil cools down. Hence the abstraction capacity must not be higher than 40 to 60 Watt per meter of tube length. Over several years of operation a new state of equilibrium can be detected where the soil temperature is lower than if no borehole heat exchanger were in operation. ;;The heat flowing towards the tube does not derive from variations in temperature but from earth’s interior. These heat flows, which have an intensity of 60 to 80 W/m2 derive by 80 % from the decay of radioactive isotopes in rocks and by 20 % from heat arising by reason of the origin of Earth.;;References:;M.Heckenberger, K.O. Luik, N.Scheirle, K.Wachter "Erdwärme in Oberschwaben", En¬ergiewirt¬schaftliche Tagesfragen 39(3), 116, 1989.;Persönliche Mitteilung einer Mitarbeiterin, Firma: HAKA, Gossau, Juli 1993.;Persönliche Mitteilung Herr Schlander, Firma: Grundag AG, Gossau, August 1993.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=CH
Estimation.The estimation of a borehole heat exchanger unit is based on the reference values for a one family house. To estimate the necessary probe length, 15 meters of probe per 1 kW of required thermal output are assumed. Based on the average cooling capacity and the extract performance a length of 150 meters can be estimated (two borehole heat exchangers with a length of 75 meters each are also possible). 

Life time of the borehole heat exchanger ranges between 30 and 100 years. In the dataset a life time of 50 years is assumed with an uncertainty of SDg2=2.

Further references:

Luder F.: Materialien für Erdwärmesonden. http://www.geothermie.de/. Retrieved 04 Mar 2003.

Arbeitsgemeinschaft Wärmepumpen, "Allgemeine Information über Wärmepumpenheizungsanla-gen - Merkblatt A 1 und A 8", 1991.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=RER
Estimation. Two U-shaped probe tubes are installed. In the cross section this amounts to four tubes, i.e. 600 meters of polyethylene tubes at a probe length of 150 meters. Assuming material amount of 0,3 kg/m (incl. losses) this amounts to 180 kg of polyethylene.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=DE
Estimation. Calcium bentonite is mined in the South of Germany. On average 10 m3 of bentonite are added to the drilling water during drilling phase. Furthermore bentonite is used for backfilling the probe. The bentonite drilling fluid prevents the collapsing of the drill wall and gives the borehole cuttings a boost. For one probe 250 kg of bentonite are used for the drilling phase and 80 kg for backfilling the probe.Due to the fact that large amounts of bentonite are recycled, in total only 8 kg of bentonite are consumed. Recycling process of bentonite is not included.

exchanges.description:
Estimation. The drilling scaffold is transported by a Unimog 1300 and is positioned at the drilling site by a lorry. The drill pipes are operated hydraulically by the Unimog engine. In the same way the pump is operated, which is used for rinsing during drilling phase and for pumping down the bentonite-cement suspension. Data regarding diesel consumption is derived from Rohner. According to this information, 2,5 liters of diesel per meter probe are used in case of hydraulic-circulation drilling; 3,5 liters per meter of probe are used in case of hammer drilling. (40 % of probes are installed with hydraulic-circulation drilling, 60 % with hammer drilling). On average approximately 2.5*0.4+3.5*0.6=3.1 liters of diesel per meter are used. 

Based on these estimations average diesel consumption for a probe with a length of 150 meters amounts to 465 l (i.e. 17700 MJ). Emissions during drilling phase are included.
EcoSpold01Location=GLO

exchanges.description: Calculated value based on literature values and expert opinion. See comments in the parametres' comment field.

Calculated value. The calculation of brine content and the associated amount of ethylene glycol is based on the percentage weighting of installed probe sizes (diameter) of 25 mm (wall thickness 2,3 mm) respectively 32 mm (wall thickness 3 mm). 30 % of probes have 25 mm of diameter (brine content: 3.27 dl/m tube), 70 % have 32 mm (brine content: 5.31 dl/m tube). Based on this weighting a brine content of 300 liters can be calculated. With an assumed antifreeze ratio of 30 % this corresponds to 90 l (i.e. 102 kg) ethylene glycol per probe. The mass density of ethylene glycol is 1,14 kg/dm3; the water amount of the brine is 210 kg.
EcoSpold01Location=RER

exchanges.description:
Estimation. During drilling phase (hydraulic-circulating drilling) waste of 1 m3 of stones and bentonite suspension is generated with an average mass density of 2500 kg/m3. The waste is deposited at a landfill for inert matter. After operation the probe is left in situ.
